thread.title: Cory Bernardi split: if it wasn't for bad luck, Malcolm Turnbull would have no luck at all
thread.title_full: Cory Bernardi split: if it wasn't for bad luck, Malcolm Turnbull would have no luck at all

author: Mark Kenny
title: Cory Bernardi split: if it wasn't for bad luck, Malcolm Turnbull would have no luck at all
text:
Is senator Corey Bernardi about to defect? Is senator Corey Bernardi about to defect? 
There is speculation Liberal senator Cory Bernardi is set to leave the Coalition to create his own conservative movement. More videos Malcolm Turnbull's crucial fortnight 
He's starting the year with poor polling numbers, so Malcolm Turnbull needs some wins as parliament resumes, says Mark Kenny. 
Consider the pattern. Adrift on a sea of electoral ennui since January's robo-debt/pension cuts and the MPs' expenses scandal, Turnbull moved to wrest control of national politics last Wednesday with his National Press Club speech. 
Yet somehow, he had chosen the very day the political donations for last year's election would become public - minus, it turned out, his own $1.75 million gift. Under intense pressure, Turnbull spilled the quantum on Wednesday night, proving the original decision to conceal it until 2018 had been naive. Related Content Politics live: Cory Bernardi quits Turnbull government as Parliament returns for the year 
The donations story truncated the usual extended analysis of his speech. 
Perhaps even this was a stroke of luck given what it had emphasised: expensive, unsupported business tax relief; unpopular welfare cuts; and Turnbull's jarring Abbott-like embrace of coal as good for Australia and the world. It might have been music to the party room, but for voters searching for the old green-tinged Turnbull, it simply underlined his disappearance. Advertisement 
In any event, the secrecy focus was itself "Trumped" by lunchtime the next day when the Washington Post broke Turnbull's toxic telephone stoush with the new US President. 
Cue the weekend. Monday brought a significant slump in the Coalition's primary vote according to Newspoll and then even this bad news was upstaged by the imminent defection of a Liberal senator who would use the first parliamentary day of 2017 to jump ship. SHARE
